name: YC Application Evolution
description: A YC application draft evolves across eight revisions as claims are tightened, metrics corrected, customer insight deepened, and risk posture made credible.

versions.content:
YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Ariana Kim

What are you building
RelayOps is an AI operations copilot for logistics teams. We automate exception handling in shipment operations where humans currently copy data between carrier portals, email threads, and spreadsheets.

What is the problem
Mid-market shippers lose hours every day resolving damaged freight claims, delayed handoffs, and address correction loops. Existing TMS platforms store status but do not execute the exception workflow end to end.

Current product statement
We ingest events from carriers and warehouse systems, classify issues, suggest next actions, and draft outbound communication. Ops leads can approve or edit before execution.

Traction snapshot
We have 6 pilot customers and strong enthusiasm from users.

Why now
Large language models can finally parse messy shipment communication and unstructured documents at useful accuracy. Logistics teams are under margin pressure and need headcount leverage.

Long-term vision
Become the workflow layer for every post-booking shipment exception.

Application tone
Bold and high-conviction. This draft is intentionally aggressive.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Devin Rao

What are you building
RelayOps is an exception-resolution workflow platform for logistics teams with AI assistance built into each decision step.

What is the problem
Ops teams process thousands of edge-case tickets where data is incomplete and resolution policy varies by customer contract. Current systems track state but do not coordinate action owners.

Current product statement
We ingest event streams and inbox messages, detect exception types, route to the right queue, and generate policy-aware action drafts. Human approvers remain in the loop for high-risk actions.

Technical architecture note
Model output is constrained by deterministic policy checks before outbound actions are allowed. We are not running fully autonomous execution.

Traction snapshot
6 pilot logos remain active, but usage quality varies by account and lane type.

What changed in this draft
Removed language implying full automation.
Clarified human-in-the-loop boundaries.
Clarified that reliability and policy correctness are more important than demo speed.

Why now
Data exhaust from logistics systems is rich but underused. Better model orchestration and policy systems now make operational automation practical without fully removing human control.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Mina Lopez

What are you building
RelayOps is workflow infrastructure for shipment exceptions. We reduce manual triage and response time for logistics ops teams.

Who feels the pain
Dispatch managers and customer operations leads at freight brokers and 3PLs.

Proof users want this
Across pilot accounts, team leads report same-day reduction in backlog once we route and draft first response. Users care less about AI novelty and more about faster closure and fewer escalations.

Traction snapshot
6 pilots in progress.
4 accounts have weekly active users.
2 accounts are still in setup and not yet stable.

Commercial direction in this draft
Shifted from broad top-of-funnel language to narrow ICP narrative.
Added clearer target buyer and workflow entry point.
Added repeatable ROI framing around backlog reduction and resolution time.

Why now
Teams are being asked to maintain service levels without adding headcount. Point tools do not solve cross-system coordination.

Application positioning
Less hype, more concrete buyer pain and measurable impact.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Ariana Kim

What are you building
RelayOps helps logistics ops teams resolve shipment exceptions by combining system ingestion, policy checks, queue routing, and assisted communication.

Customer evidence
We re-ran account-level metrics to avoid overclaiming. Prior draft language implied broad traction too early.

Updated traction snapshot
6 pilots signed.
4 live with weekly usage.
3 showing meaningful workflow adoption beyond first week.
1 account paused due to internal IT delay.

Early outcomes where data is clean
Median first-response time down 31 percent in live accounts.
Escalation-to-manager rate down 18 percent on handled exception types.

What changed in this draft
Removed ambiguous phrase "strong enthusiasm".
Added account-quality breakdown.
Added measured outcomes with explicit scope limits.

Open weakness we now state directly
Current product handles a subset of exception types well, not full exception universe.

Application tone
Still ambitious, but now grounded in measurable and defensible claims.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Priya Nwosu

What are you building
RelayOps is a decision-support workflow layer for shipment exceptions, focused first on damaged freight and delayed handoff categories.

Customer discovery synthesis
We interviewed 17 operations leaders in freight brokerage and 3PL environments.
Most teams are not asking for full autonomy. They want predictable routing, policy consistency, and faster first response.

Top adoption blockers identified
Policy mismatch across customer contracts.
Data quality gaps from carrier event feeds.
Trust concerns when automated drafts sound generic or overly confident.

Product refinements based on discovery
Narrowed initial category focus to high-volume exception types with cleaner policy boundaries.
Added mandatory confidence and rationale snippets for every suggested action.
Added per-customer policy profile as core onboarding step.

Traction snapshot retained
6 pilots signed, 4 live, 3 showing sustained usage.

What changed in this draft
Shifted narrative from broad automation platform to narrow wedge with explicit expansion path.
Added blockers section to show honest understanding of implementation risk.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Iris Patel

What are you building
RelayOps provides assisted workflow execution for shipment exceptions with human approval controls and audit logging.

Compliance and liability language update
Prior versions used language that could imply autonomous decisioning. This version clarifies that high-impact actions require human approval and that policy checks are mandatory pre-send controls.

Data handling posture
We process operational shipment data and communication metadata.
We do not require storage of sensitive identity documents for core workflow categories in current scope.

Risk controls now described in application
Audit trail for suggested and approved actions.
Role-based approval thresholds by customer.
Configurable policy constraints before outbound communication.

Traction and product scope retained from V5
6 pilots signed, 4 live, 3 sustained.
Focused category wedge remains damaged freight and delayed handoff.

What changed in this draft
Removed legal-risky wording around autonomous resolution.
Added explicit guardrail language and approval boundaries.
Strengthened credibility of enterprise readiness narrative.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Noah Feld

What are you building
RelayOps improves exception-resolution throughput for logistics operations teams with policy-aware assisted workflows.

Revenue and pricing clarity added
Prior draft avoided concrete commercial structure. This version adds current pricing model and conversion assumptions.

Current commercial snapshot
2 pilots converted to paid annual contracts.
Blended ACV for converted accounts is 54 thousand.
Pipeline includes 9 qualified accounts in similar segment.

Unit-economic signal in current stage
Onboarding effort is still high and must be reduced for scale.
Gross margin profile appears healthy if support load declines after onboarding templates mature.

What changed in this draft
Added paid conversion data and ACV.
Removed implied near-term hypergrowth language.
Added explicit scaling bottleneck around onboarding cost.

Honest risk statement
If we do not productize onboarding in the next two quarters, growth will remain services-constrained.

YC Application Working Draft
Company name: RelayOps
Primary editor: Ariana Kim

What are you building
RelayOps is a policy-aware workflow system for logistics exception handling. We reduce resolution time and escalation load by routing issues, generating constrained action drafts, and keeping humans in approval control for higher-risk actions.

Who this is for
Initial segment is mid-market freight brokers and 3PL operators with high exception volume and fragmented tools.

Current traction summary
6 pilots signed.
4 live.
3 with sustained weekly usage.
2 converted to paid annual contracts at 54 thousand blended ACV.

What works today
Faster first response and lower escalation rates in the exception categories we support.
Strong buyer interest when we frame value as operational throughput and policy consistency.

What is still hard
Onboarding is too manual.
Data quality varies across carrier integrations.
Coverage is strong for selected categories but incomplete for long-tail exceptions.

Why now
Teams need headcount leverage and control consistency, not more dashboarding.
Model capability plus policy-constrained orchestration makes this feasible now in workflows that were previously too messy.

What we are asking YC to believe
We can win by starting with one painful wedge, proving measurable workflow value, and expanding category coverage while keeping trust and control intact.

Founder note
This final version intentionally favors credibility over hype and reflects what we have actually learned in pilots.
